message: I’m back in Washington for the start of the 115th Congress. As we enter the New Year, House Republicans are ready to hit the ground running, working to restore accountability within the federal government and advance real change for the American people.  I’m honored to serve the great people of Nevada, and look forward to passing much needed reforms in regards to healthcare, immigration, and our economy.   What priorities would you like to see the 115th Congress tackle? Send me an email: https://amodei.house.gov/email-me/.

Head over to my website, https://amodei.house.gov/nevada-flood-information-staying-prepared/, for information regarding the severe flooding in Washoe County, how to stay informed, and basic safety tips.   We are tracking updates and staying in touch with local officials, Governor Sandoval’s office, and federal agencies. If you have any questions or concerns please do not hesitate to call my Reno office at: 775-686-5760. We’re happy to assist in any way possible. Please continue to check my website and social media pages for up to date information.

Below, the House Energy and Commerce Committee shows the negative impact Obamacare has had on American taxpayers. With only 5 of the 23 Obamacare co-ops remaining, many Americans – particularly in rural areas like Northern Nevada – have been left with fewer choices. In fact, residents in 7 counties throughout CD-2 have only one insurance provider to choose from this year. Not only has the President’s failed healthcare law left these residents with no alternative, but it inflicts a penalty tax if they do not choose the coverage that Washington says is right for them.   I plan to offer much-needed relief to these Nevadans by reintroducing a bill that will exempt residents in counties with less than two provider options from this unfair tax. I also look forward to joining my colleagues this week as we pave the way for a stable transition to patient-centered solutions that will expand access to quality and affordable care.

UPDATE: As we continue to track updates and keep in touch with local officials, Governor Sandoval’s office, and federal agencies, I wanted to share information from NOAA regarding the Sierra blizzard and snow potentials for Western Nevada. If you have any questions or concerns please do not hesitate to call my Reno office at: 775-686-5760. We’re happy to assist in any way possible. Please continue to check my website and social media pages for up to date information.

Head over to my website to view my response to the President’s immigration executive order. After taking time to contact several local entities in Nevada and relevant federal agencies, it is our understanding that no individuals in CD-2 have been impacted by this order. With respect to Southern Nevada, we understand that  three cases are affected. We’ve determined potential impacts, and if people need help – we’re here to assist. If my colleagues in Southern Nevada need help, I’m here for them as well.  You might be interested to know that I voted in favor of the Visa Waiver Program Improvement and Terrorist Travel Prevention Act last Congress. This bipartisan bill overwhelmingly passed the House in 2015 and was signed into law by then-President Barack Obama through its inclusion in the FY16 Omnibus. The countries affected under President Trump’s executive order were originally listed in this Act, meaning his order is built largely off existing law to provide the Department of Homeland Security with the additional time it needs to integrate effective protocols for visa applicants.  Click below to learn more and read my full statement:

I'll be hosting a veterans' town hall meeting in Winnemucca on Friday, February 10, from 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., inside the Meeting Room of the Humboldt County Library located at 85 East Fifth Street. If you’re a veteran in the area, please come out to learn more about the ways we can best serve you. Tracy Soliday in our Reno Office is available to answer any question at: (775) 686-5760.

The worldwide symbol of democracy and freedom should not be disrespected… let alone desecrated. As Americans, we have a duty to ensure future generations understand the power and value of the American flag. Today, I teamed up with 13 of my colleagues to introduce H.J.Res.61, a bill that will give us the ability to protect our flag. America was founded by the people, for the people. Share this post if you agree that it’s time to let us, not courts, decide how to treat our flag.

This week, I delivered the Congressional Western Caucus's weekly address, discussing some of the issues that are critical to Western states. In Nevada, 4 out of every 5 acres of land is owned by the federal government – the highest percentage of federal land ownership in any state. Click below to learn more about the challenges facing our state and Nevada’s history in terms of federal lands bills.

Hailing from all branches of the Military, Vietnam helicopter pilots and crewmembers account for nearly ten percent of all Vietnam casualties. These pilots and crewmembers touched every aspect of efforts during the war, serving as transportation for soldiers and civilians, and providing critical battlefield support. However, there is currently no national monument honoring their joint sacrifice. The Vietnam Helicopter Crew Monument Act, legislation I reintroduced today, will ensure this deserving group of American heroes finally receives proper recognition – an honor that is rightfully deserved after more than 40 years. Learn more here: http://bit.ly/2kACzx3

Congratulations to the Davidson Academy in Reno for winning the regional competition in the 2017 National Science Bowl. Taking home this win means these talented students have secured a spot to compete in the national finals in Washington this spring. With more than 14,000 students competing each year, the National Science Bowl is one of the nation’s largest and most competitive science competitions. Please join me in congratulating these students on a job well done. I wish them the best of luck as they advance to nationals.

Just introduced a bipartisan initiative to jump-start economic development throughout Pershing County while promoting conservation. This legislation represents a decade of grassroots efforts by the people of Pershing County – including residents, ranchers, miners, conservationists, and Commissioners – to resolve areas designated as suitable for transfer, checkerboard lands along I-80, and areas with wilderness characteristics within Pershing County. I look forward to seeing this effort through the legislative process and what that brings.
It's always nice to see familiar faces while I’m in Washington. Here are some of the Nevadans I met with this week:

Thank you to everyone who came out to yesterday’s lunch at the Carson City Chamber. I always welcome direct input from Nevadans, so I was happy to see this event turn into an open and honest discussion. I realize yesterday’s event was well attended and that a number of constituents were unable to participate, so I look forward to continuing this conversation at my upcoming town hall in Reno. I hope to see you all there. I will continue making myself as visible as possible throughout CD-2 because staying in contact with people in every corner of Northern Nevada is the primary purpose of my job.    As always, if you or someone you know is in need of immediate assistance with a federal agency, please do not hesitate to call my Reno office at: 775-686-5760. We're happy to help.

The Obama Administration’s Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS) rule is a sweeping regulation that has caused detrimental consequences for landowners in the West. President Trump’s decision today to review and reconsider this rule is great news for Nevada’s farmers, ranchers, and agricultural workers whose rights have been significantly undermined because of WOTUS. I hope to finally see this regulation eliminated and replaced with something reasonable that allows America’s landowners to do their jobs as effectively and responsibly as possible.

Today, we celebrate a proud moment in Nevada’s history: on this day in 1919, Clara Crowell was sworn in as Lander County’s first woman Sheriff. Clara was sworn in only months before the 19th Amendment was passed through Congress, a powerful and memorable moment in the women’s rights movement. As the proud father of two strong women, one who pursued a career in engineering and served our nation in the U.S. Navy and the other who is a certified nurse, I realize firsthand the importance of encouraging girls at an early age to become leaders in our communities and in the workplace. In fact, a majority the top paying positions on my staff are filled by women and the majority of my 14 employees are also women. As we continue to celebrate Women’s History Month, I ask that you join me in honoring the incredible contributions made by women across the world.

This week, the House introduced legislation to replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. I’m sure you have questions and are looking for specifics about the bill, so I wanted to share the bill with you here: https://housegop.leadpages.co/healthcare/. I’ve also sent out a special edition newsletter today regarding the healthcare proposal and where I stand. You may view that here: https://amodei.house.gov/enewsletters-archive/.  I ask that you take a moment to review the bill and let me know what you think. As always, I welcome your thoughts and feedback. To ensure you don’t miss out on similar updates, remember to sign up for my newsletter if you haven’t already at: https://amodei.house.gov/newsletter-sign-up/

ICYMI: This week, the Vietnam Helicopter Pilots Association (VHPA) voted to accept the Arlington National Cemetery (ANC) management board’s proposal to place a monument within ANC, honoring the nearly 5,000 helicopter pilots and crew members killed in action while serving in Vietnam. In 2015 – the year of the 50th Commemoration of the Vietnam War – the VHPA submitted a proposal for a memorial to be placed in ANC, but the Secretary of the Army declined their proposal. Since first learning the process had failed these veterans, I’ve been committed to advancing this effort through the House for the past two Congresses. With more than 40 years having passed since the end of the Vietnam War, I’m pleased to know this group of deserving veterans will finally receive proper recognition – an honor that is long overdue. Head over to my website to learn more: www.amodei.house.gov

If you missed my interview with MSNBC’s Steve Kornacki on the American Health Care Act, you can view our entire conversation below.  I continue to welcome your thoughts and feedback and want you to know that my mind will be made up based on if I believe this bill is sensible for Nevada.

UPDATE: In regards to the American Health Care Act, we’ve done our homework, we’ve closed on the issue – and I’m a no. As I’ve said since the beginning of this process, I will make up my mind based on what the House has accomplished in terms of fixing the top-line issues and if this bill is sensible for Nevada. Learn more about my decision by watching my interview from earlier today with MSNBC’s Ali Velshi.

My staff and I will continue to evaluate any and all suggestions and changes in regards to the American Health Care Act. It’s important to note that most health care reform issues must be resolved through legislation that requires 60 votes in the Senate and extensive regulatory work by HHS Secretary Tom Price. While I will continue to keep an open mind, if the current plan is the bill that comes to the Floor for a vote –  I will not be supporting it. Learn why in my latest health care update: https://amodei.house.gov/enewsletters-archive/

ON THIS DAY IN NEVADA HISTORY: Reno, “The Biggest Little City in the World,” was officially founded in 1868. In 1859, Charles W. Fuller built a log toll bridge across the Truckee River to provide the necessary connection between Virginia City and the California Trail. A few years later, Fuller sold the bridge to Myron C. Lake, who continued to  operate the bridge and lodging accommodations, renaming the developing community "Lake's Crossing".   After the arrival of the Central Pacific Railroad in 1868, Lake sold most of the land to the Railroad in exchange for a depot. Once the railroad station was built, a town site was laid out, and the town of Reno officially came into being 149 years ago today. Charles Crocker, the Railroad’s construction superintendent, named the community after Major General Jesse Lee Reno, a Union officer killed in the American Civil War at the Battle of South Mountain.  #HomeMeansNevada #BattleBorn   Photo source: University Libraries, UNR

Recently, my office presented Major Christy Hales, Nevada Army National Guard Director of Military Family Support Services, with a certificate of recognition. Major Hales has been in incredible asset to our community, working hard to reduce the unemployment rate of Guardsmen, their families, veterans, spouses, DoD reserve personnel and Gold Star families. I thank Major Hales for all that she has done for our state and wish her the best of luck as she moves on to the California National Guard State Partnership Program.

This week is National Police Week, a time to honor the brave men and women who work hard each day to protect our communities. With their service comes great risk and sacrifice, and I ask that you join me in recognizing all of Nevada’s police officers. My office recently attended the 30th annual James D. Hoff Peace Officer Memorial Ceremony in Reno to remember those who have fallen in the line of duty. I'd like to take a moment to thank all of Nevada’s current, former, and fallen officers – our communities are extremely grateful for your service.

The results are in! Congratulations to Reno’s Aubrey Milner of Robert McQueen High School for winning CD-2’s 2017 Congressional Art Competition for her piece entitled: “Home Means Nevada”. Aubrey’s work will be displayed at the U.S. Capitol for one year and she will also have the opportunity to travel to Washington to attend a congratulatory ceremony with the winners of other Congressional districts. I’d also like to commend our runner up: Anna Benedict of Robert McQueen High School for her piece, “Battle Born” and our 3rd place winner: Makenna Wheeler of Bishop Manogue Catholic High School in Reno for her piece, “Paracosm”. As always, I’m incredibly proud of all of the talented young artists that participated in this year’s competition and I commend them on their outstanding work.

I enjoyed visiting with everyone who came out to the Grand Army of the Republic (GAR) Cemetery in Reno and the Veterans Cemetery Memorial Event in Fernley last weekend. It was an honor to spend the day remembering all the brave men and women in our Armed Forces who have made the ultimate sacrifice to keep us safe and free. I would also like to recognize those who continue to serve our country with honor and distinction. I hope that all of you had a safe and enjoyable Memorial Day.

ICYMI: Today, I joined MSNBC’s Ali Velshi to talk about the state of health care in Nevada and the lack of regular order surrounding this issue as it moves through Congress. Be sure to check out the clip below to hear our full discussion. As always, I encourage you to share your thoughts and concerns with me below or email me through my website: https://amodei.house.gov/email-me/.

HEALTH CARE UPDATE: Anthem just announced its pulling out of 6 counties in CD-2 come 2018 – leaving residents in Churchill, Elko, Pershing, Eureka, Humboldt, and Lander counties without a single provider to choose from. Regardless of your political views, this is proof the status quo isn’t working and that our system is in need of serious repair. I’d rather be criticized for attempting to move an issue toward a solution, than criticized for repeated inaction. This is why I will continue to focus on the facts, with the goal of ensuring that any reform package increases access to care while paying respect to rural communities like ours that are being hit the hardest right now.

For those who will no longer have access to health care at the end of the year though the Nevada exchange due to Anthem’s departure, you may contact the Access to Health Care Network, a non-profit organization that connects Nevadans with health care providers.   Access to Health Care Network: Address: Reno Town Mall, 4001 S Virginia St., Reno, NV 89502 Phone: (775) 284-8989 or 1-877-385-2345 Website: http://www.accesstohealthcare.org/  You  may also seek assistance and additional information about Anthem’s departure through the Silver State Exchange:   Phone: 1-855- 768-5465  Website: www.nevadahealthlink.com

I’m currently seeking highly motivated college students to intern in my Washington office for the Fall 2017 session, which includes mid-August through December. Candidates should possess an interest in the legislative process, strong communication skills and attention to detail. Responsibilities include: answering phones, leading U.S. Capitol tours, attending committee hearings, and performing various other tasks based on skills and interests. A qualified applicant will possess excellent oral and written communications skills and a willingness to work on a variety of tasks. Nevada ties preferred. Interested candidates should send their cover letter and resume to: nv.internship@gmail.com. REMINDER: there is currently a rolling deadline for the Fall 2017 session. Please visit: http://amodei.house.gov/students for additional information.

As I prepare to head back to Washington next week, I wanted to share some highlights from the August District Work Period with you. Combined, my staff and I traveled more than 5,500 miles and took over 160 meetings with constituents, organizations, local business, and federal agencies. Spending an extended period of time home in CD-2, also allowed me to host several round table discussions and a veterans town hall meeting. Thank you to everyone who took the time to meet with us. I’m eager to take your thoughts, ideas, and concerns, back with me to Washington.   I also wanted to remind any veterans who were unable to attend Tuesday’s town hall in Minden, and are in need of assistance, to please contact Tracy Soliday in my Reno office at 775-686-5760. We’re happy to help in any way we can.   Finally, please make sure you’re signed up for the Amodei Report, my e-newsletter, if you’re not already. It’s a great way to stay up to date with the work I’m doing in Washington and Nevada. Sign up through my website to make sure you don’t miss out on any important information: https://amodei.house.gov/newsletter-sign-up/.

“Unfathomable evil. Attacking harmless people who like listening to music – I don’t have the words. Our hearts go out to the victims and families of this terrible tragedy. It’s a sad day.” https://amodei.house.gov/news-releases/amodei-responds-to-las-vegas-shooting/

When you talk about Nevada-resilience – it’s a pretty humbling thing. Over the past couple of days, I’ve been incredibly encouraged by the outpouring of support displayed by those on the ground in Vegas, lending a hand to help their fellow Americans in any way possible. Today, I joined the president as we made our way to Nevada to visit the victims and first responders involved in this terrible tragedy. I will continue to closely monitor this investigation and share new details as I receive them. Even in the worst situations, America continues to prove it is a resilient nation, coming together in the face of unfathomable evil to help one another.

Did you receive my e-newsletter this week? It’s a great way to stay up to date with the work I’m doing in Washington and Nevada. REMINDER FOR STUDENTS: The deadline to submit Service Academy applications is fast approaching. Interested students are strongly encouraged to apply by the October 31 deadline. If you have any questions, please contact Tracy Soliday in our Reno office at (775) 686-5760 or visit amodei.house.gov/academy-nominations for more details. Happy Nevada Day! Today, we celebrate 153 years of Nevada’s statehood. Twenty years ago, I introduced legislation to observe Nevada Day as the last Friday of October, ensuring that every hardworking Nevadan has an opportunity to celebrate our statehood and rich heritage. I’m proud to be a 4th generation Nevadan and I wish our great state a very happy birthday!

I’m currently seeking highly motivated college students and recent graduates to participate in a paid internship in my Washington office for the spring 2018 semester – which includes January through mid-May. Qualified candidates should possess an interest in the legislative process, excellent organizational, writing, and communication skills, and a willingness to work on a variety of projects.   Responsibilities include: answering phones, leading tours of the U.S. Capitol, attending committee hearings, and performing various other tasks based on interests and skills. Nevada ties are a plus, but not required. Special consideration will be given to applicants from CD-2 or students attending Nevada institutions of higher education. Interested candidates should send their cover letter and resume to: nv02applications@gmail.com. APPLICATION DEADLINE: DECEMBER 1st. Visit the student section of my website for additional details: https://amodei.house.gov/students/

As you may know, this week the House Republican Conference unveiled the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a comprehensive plan to reform our nation’s tax system. I’m sure you have questions about the bill, so I wanted to share a summary of the bill with you you below. Now that we have a starting point to work with, my staff and I plan to take a deep dive into this legislation to understand how these policy reforms will affect Nevadans. We are specifically going to analyze the individual applications, the business applications, and also determine if any health care applications are included. I think we can all agree the American taxpayer would be better off if Congress were to reform our current tax code in favor of a system that is simpler, fairer, and has lower tax rates.  At this point, I am unsure of the Speaker’s timeline for moving this through the House or how my colleagues in the Senate will react to this bill. So in the meantime, all hands are on deck in my Washington office as we work to break down the specifics of this legislation and determine what it might mean for our economy. We will also be seeking input from local stakeholders in Nevada and across the country.

In Case You Missed It: Below is a great example of the kind of assistance my Reno office provides to the people of CD-2 each day. Our constituent services efforts have always been centered around the following values: access and responsiveness. When Nevadans cannot get the answers they need from a federal agency, or if they have been treated unfairly, our job is to intervene on your behalf. If you or someone you know is experiencing a similar situation, or needs help with another federal agency, please do not hesitate to call my Reno office at 775-686-5760 or contact me via my website at: https://amodei.house.gov/email-me/. This is why we’re here.

As you may know, today the House Ways and Means Committee passed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a comprehensive plan to reform our nation’s tax system.   If you’re a student, individual or joint filer, or one of the 25% of Nevadans who currently itemize your taxes, I’m sure you have several questions about how the measures in this bill might affect you and your family should it become law. Since the bill’s introduction last Thursday, my Washington office has been working diligently to analyze all 429 pages of this legislation. I also took time to go through your recent Facebook comments to ensure we answered a number of your concerns. From how this bill might affect the deficit, to how it could affect certain deductions and middle-income earners, I hope you head over to my website to view the special edition tax reform update I just sent out. You may do so by clicking the link below.   Please let me know what you think. Also, If there are any questions you would like me to address in my next update please let me know.   As always, I thank you for your input and hope that you have a safe and enjoyable Veterans’ Day weekend.

Thanks to those who have offered feedback through my office and on my last Facebook post about the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. After hearing your concerns, another aspect of the tax proposal I would like to address is the potential elimination of the medical tax deduction.   If you’re one of the 6% of Americans who currently claim this deduction, and would like to know how the elimination of this deduction might affect you should this bill become law, you will need to compare your current medical expenses against the increased standard deductions under the new proposal ($12,000 for individuals and $24,000 for joint filers). Click below to find out how calculate this figure based on your adjusted gross income and to learn more about the additional facts surrounding this deduction.   If your out-of-pocket medical expenses do not exceed the new standard deductions for individual and joint filers, you and your family may better off financially under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.

Click below to learn more about my vote on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and how this bill will result in simplified filing and a tax cut for the vast majority of CD-2 federal taxpayers. I encourage individual and joint filers to compare last year’s tax return to the new plan by using the increased standard deductions and lower tax brackets to see what their treatment is individually. However, for the average household in CD-2 with an annual income of $65,000, the federal tax cut affect is over $12,000 a year with the new brackets and standard deductions. This represents the beginning of the legislative process on tax reform. All eyes now turn to the Senate as they work on a tax reform bill that is not identical to this one.
